parameter 1: In the R rated version which most video rental store carry every last drop of blood has been removed.
parameter 2: The UK cinema version was extensively cut by the BBFC upon release with edits to the opening staking, shots of dismembered body parts in the laboratory and a reduction to a scene where a tube is inserted into a man's neck to drain blood. Additionally the infamous dungeon scene, showing potential female victims chained to a wall, was completely removed. The 2005 UK DD Entertainment DVD features the same cut cinema print. The U.S Dark Sky DVD may be culled from a different print as the tube scene is completely intact, despite missing the other aforementioned BBFC cuts.
parameter 3: The earliest version was Psycho a Go-Go, with new footage being added for Fiend with the Electronic Brain. After more footage was added it became Blood of Ghastly Horror.
parameter 4: The Directors cut is 9 minutes longer than the theatrical cut of the film.
parameter 5: Director Al Adamson filmed the first version, Echo of Terror, a straightforward heist movie, in 1964. Adamson and producer Sam Sherman could not interest any distributor in releasing the movie. Several new scenes were added in 1965 (some featured actor John Carradine) and the result was a more horrific, science-fiction themed version, Psycho A Go-Go. That version was also unreleasable. Allied Artists TV approached Sherman with a request for a color horror movie to add to their package of movies for sale to American TV stations. Adamson responded by filming new scenes that added a zombie and mad doctor subplot, featuring Tommy Kirk, Kent Taylor and Regina Carroll, and the vastly re-edited film was sold to TV as The Man With The Synthetic Brain. A few scenes were cut for TV (including a strangulation murder), but Adamson added the violence and gore into a theatrical version of Synthetic Brain, titled Blood of Ghastly Horror.
parameter 6: The 18-rated UK release of this film was cut by 29 seconds by the BBFC.
parameter 7: The 2001 Tartan Video UK DVD release was cut by the BBFC to remove 23 secs of shots of Ramses's whip hitting the girl in his back room. These were replaced with shots of the statue's head and Ramses's face. The BBFC waived these cuts for the 2005 Odeon DVD issue.
parameter 8: There is additional footage of Karl tormenting some chained female victims and also more of his death and some bloody lab shots in a version released on VHS in France in the 80s.
parameter 9: The 1989 UK video was pre-cut by over 2 minutes and then cut by a further 2 min 51 secs by the BBFC.
parameter 10: An alternate TV version entitled "Dracula's Castle" includes footage featuring a werewolf that was not part of the original film. This version runs 91 minutes.
parameter 11: The earliest version was Psycho a Go-Go, with new footage being added for Fiend with the Electronic Brain. After more footage was added it became Blood of Ghastly Horror.
parameter 12: The UK cinema version was extensively cut by the BBFC upon release with edits to the opening staking, shots of dismembered body parts in the laboratory and a reduction to a scene where a tube is inserted into a man's neck to drain blood. Additionally the infamous dungeon scene, showing potential female victims chained to a wall, was completely removed. The 2005 UK DD Entertainment DVD features the same cut cinema print. The U.S Dark Sky DVD may be culled from a different print as the tube scene is completely intact, despite missing the other aforementioned BBFC cuts.
parameter 13: After premiering at 106m, film was cut to 93m; some of the cut footage was edited to earn an "R" rating, replacing than the original "X".
parameter 14: In the R Rated version, Jason Pace's death was edited by about 20 seconds. The Unrated Director's Cut (available on DVD), features the longer/bloodier death scene, which just has more blood.
parameter 15: The earliest version was Psycho a Go-Go, with new footage being added for Fiend with the Electronic Brain. After more footage was added it became Blood of Ghastly Horror.
parameter 16: An alternate TV version entitled "Dracula's Castle" includes footage featuring a werewolf that was not part of the original film. This version runs 91 minutes.
parameter 17: The earliest version was Psycho a Go-Go, with new footage being added for Fiend with the Electronic Brain. After more footage was added it became Blood of Ghastly Horror.
parameter 18: Although the UK cinema version didn't suffer as many cuts as _Flesh for Frankenstein (1973)_ (qv) it was edited by around 4 minutes by the BBFC with extensive cuts to the sex scenes and edits to shots of the Count drinking and then vomiting up blood. The 1995 First Independent video version and all subsequent UK releases were fully uncut.
parameter 19: The 2003 U.S DVD on the Retro Media label is heavily pre-edited and missing footage of nudity and violence including a brief full-frontal shot of Jill in the shower and a throat slashing.
parameter 20: The 2001 Tartan Video UK DVD release was cut by the BBFC to remove 23 secs of shots of Ramses's whip hitting the girl in his back room. These were replaced with shots of the statue's head and Ramses's face. The BBFC waived these cuts for the 2005 Odeon DVD issue.
parameter 21: An alternate TV version entitled "Dracula's Castle" includes footage featuring a werewolf that was not part of the original film. This version runs 91 minutes.
parameter 22: The earliest version was Psycho a Go-Go, with new footage being added for Fiend with the Electronic Brain. After more footage was added it became Blood of Ghastly Horror.
parameter 23: The video release contains some minor differences in the music cues, and some transitions between scenes, from the original version screened at the December, 2012 premiere. The final shot, a long shot of the warehouse, was also replaced by a black screen.
parameter 24: After premiering at 106m, film was cut to 93m; some of the cut footage was edited to earn an "R" rating, replacing than the original "X".
parameter 25: The 1989 UK video was pre-cut by over 2 minutes and then cut by a further 2 min 51 secs by the BBFC.
